marklogic.body:
I'm sorry for your situation. But McCarthy has worked tirelessly supporting this claim that has been known false for several years. I feel no less sorry for her that she is short on answers. We NEED to find a cure for autism, and if there is a genetic marker ... or something ... that makes some kids susceptible, then yeah. We definitely need to study that.
But I can't condone anything less than 100% condemnation of Wakefield. Not only has their been a resurgence of measles and mumps, but some kids have died as a result.
Greg mocks everything. I've heard McCarthy speak, and I find her reprehensible. I understand she cares about her son and about the cause of autism. But I personally find her vile.
The fact is, if there is some sort of link between MMR vaccines, or even with measles itself, and an increase in autism, Wakefield's study has hurt the chances of finding it, because now people are convinced he is wrong. Which he is, but he's hurt the real science that might follow as a result of his scam.
For example, the thing about mercury: how much mercury is in an average Flu shot? Now how much is in a can of tuna?
I think caution and optimism are good things, but when I hear McCarthy speak, I've just as often heard panic and doom saying. That's just me. I feel differently about AIDS, as I lost a partner to AIDS, as well as about 20 friends. It's more personal, more subjective.
I understand how you feel on this issue, and on the fundamentals, I think we agree: more research, better research, more patient/parent awareness of the risks of vaccinations. For example, I never get Flu shots. Nor did I get a meningitis vaccine when I went back to University.
I just don't think we should be too hard on Gutfeld, either. McCarthy has made some bizarre statements and some ludicrous demands, along with her concern.
It's a sticky wicket. And I'm Glad so many people, especially you and Melissa - who are more closely affected by this issue than the rest of us - chimed in so eloquently.
